Hi Folks,

I am trying to implement a simple "nonuniform" grid on a square, where the center of the square is sample much more densely than the rest of the square. I wrote this code as an attempt:

```N=300
kX1 = collect(range(minimum(fullK[1, :]), stop=-0.05, length=N÷3+1))
kY1 = collect(range(minimum(fullK[2, :]), stop=-0.05, length=N÷3+1))
kX2 = collect(range(-0.05, stop=0.05, length=N÷3))
kY2 = collect(range(-0.05, stop=0.05, length=N÷3))
kX3 = collect(range(0.05, stop=maximum(fullK[1,:]), length=N÷3+1))
kY3 = collect(range(0.05, stop=maximum(fullK[2,:]), length=N÷3+1))
kX = vcat(kX1[1:end-1], kX2, kX3[2:end])
kY = vcat(kY1[1:end-1], kY2, kY3[2:end])
		
KX = repeat(kX, N)[:]
KY = repeat(kY',N)[:]
gridPoints = [KX KY]'

p = scatter(gridPoints[1,:], gridPoints[2,:], label="Grid", markersize=10, marker=:x)```
And the result is shown in the attachment.

I understand why the grid looks the way it does but can't fix it. It seems like a pretty simple problem though. Any thoughts?

messages.text:
Should `eachcol` propagate `@inbounds`? It's defined <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/blob/master/base/abstractarraymath.jl#L452|here> in terms of `view`, but a loop over columns cannot be annotated with `@inbounds` to remove the bounds checking done inside `view`:
```eachcol(A::AbstractVecOrMat) = (view(A, :, i) for i in axes(A, 2))```

Hi,

I dont understand why this code is allocating (I check it is type stable with @code_warntype). Unfortunately, it is difficult to generate a simple MWE.

In my experiments, I call  `@time prob6(Val(6), sol0, par3)` , and get
`0.000635 seconds (1.92 k allocations: 114.438 KiB)`

In the for loop, I put `@time step!(view(outu,:, i), view(u, :, i-1), view(u, :, i), h, pb.mesh[i-1])`

which gives a lot of `.000097 seconds (66 allocations: 3.906 KiB)`, so far so good because 3.8 * 30 = 117KiB and I have a forloop of length 30.
??? However why `updateCache!` allocates (apart from the lines `applyF`)?? I put `@.` everywhere????

```@with_kw_noshow struct MIRKCache6{T}
	Fi::T
	Fip05::T
	Fip1
	yi::T
	yip025::T
	yip05::T
	yip075::T
	yip1
	Fip025::T
	Fip075::T
end

function updateCache!(pb::POMIRKProblem, y, y₁, par, h, t)
    # in the following pb.cache.cache6::MIRKCache6
	@unpack Fi, Fip05, Fip1, yi, yip025, yip05, yip075, yip1, Fip025, Fip075 = pb.cache.cache6
	yip1 .= y₁
	yi .= y
	applyF(pb, Fi, yi, par, t)
	applyF(pb, Fip1, yip1, par, t + h)

	yip025 .= @. (54*yi + 10*yip1 + (9*Fi - 3*Fip1)*h)/64
	yip075 .= @. (10*yi + 54*yip1 + (3*Fi - 9*Fip1)*h)/64

	applyF(pb, Fip025, yip025, par, t + h/4)
	applyF(pb, Fip075, yip075, par, t + 3h/4)

	yip05 .= @. 0.5*(yi + yip1) - (5*Fi - 16*Fip025 + 16*Fip075 - 5*Fip1)*(h/24)
	applyF(pb, Fip05, yip05, par, t + h/2)
end

function (pb::POMIRKProblem)(::Val{6}, U::AbstractVector, par)
	M, N = size(pb)
	order = Val(6)
	T = 1
	u = getTimeSlices(pb, U)


	# define the outputs
	outu = similar(U, N, M)
	outt = similar(U, M)

	function step!(dest, y, y₁, h, t)
		# update the cache
		updateCache!(pb, y, y₁, par, h, t)
		@unpack Fi, Fip05, Fip1, yi, yip025, yip05, yip075, yip1, Fip025, Fip075 = pb.cache.cache6
		# update residual
		dest .= yip1 .- yi .- (7 .*Fi .+ 32 .*Fip025 .+ 12 .*Fip05 .+ 32 .*Fip075 .+ 7 .*Fip1).*(h/90)
	end

	# boundary conditions
	outu[:, 1] .= @views pb.bc(u[:, 1], u[:, M])

	for i in 2:length(pb)
		h = getTimeStep(pb, i) * T
		# Update residual
		step!(view(outu,:, i), view(u, :, i-1), view(u, :, i), h, pb.mesh[i-1])
	end

	return vec(outu)
end```

function (pb::POMIRKProblem)(::Val{6}, U::AbstractVector, par)

messages.text:
Is there a good reason that this code has a branch to an error call that can never happen?
```struct Foo
    x::Union{Some{Int}, Nothing}
end

f(x) = x.x === nothing ? nothing : something(x.x)
@code_native f(Foo(nothing))```
Edit: Turns out you can remove the branch by doing:
```f(x) = x.x isa Some ? something(x.x) : x.x```

messages.text:
Hi,

I am styling my Julia figures for my PhD thesis and I want them to be vector graphics and to adopt the font of my document. (So far, I used to be lazy with gr() and png or pdf outputs via savefig.) Now, I tried from here: <https://docs.juliaplots.org/latest/output/>

I tried the tex output from pgfplotsx but it did not work. So I thought I could produce a svg output via savefig and use `inkscape -D -z --file=image.svg --export-pdf=image.pdf --export-latex`  (which works well for any svg produced in inkscape). There is no errors but the export does not recognize the legend and axis labels as text in the output svg from gr(), i.e., the text does not adapt to the latex document.

I tested all the backends listed for svg output in the docs above:
svg	- gr, inspectdr, pgfplotsx, plotly, plotlyjs, pyplot

Most backends did the same thing as gr() that the text was not recognized after the inkscape export. The only one that worked was plotlyjs() but the legend positioning was a bit buggy. Good news is that it can be repositioned in latex in the pdf_tex though :-).

So, I found a way, but I just wanted to know if anyone knows a better way (since I have a lot of figures)? I did not check the source or docs in more detail so far because I haven't touched Julia code since October and have no clue about svg etc. anyway. I was hoping someone might know here.

(which works well for any svg produced in inkscape). There is no errors but the export does not recognize the legend and axis labels as text in the output svg from gr(), i.e., the text does not adapt to the latex document.

messages.text:
Here's a question about the performance of iteration over `AbstractArray` type wrappers: I am surprised that using `enumerate` over a wrapper array is sometimes slower than just using the underlying vector - but only for certain element types.

The problem is best illustrated by example:
```import Base: size, getindex, IndexStyle

# define a wrapper type over a vector
struct V{T} <: AbstractVector{T}
    x::Vector{T}
end
size(v::V) = (length(v.x),)
Base.@propagate_inbounds getindex(v::V, i::Int) = v.x[i]
IndexStyle(::Type{<:V}) = IndexLinear()

# do something with `enumerate` over this wrapper
function f(v)
    s = zero(eltype(v))
    for (i,xᵢ) in enumerate(v)   # <--
        s += xᵢ*i
    end
    return s
end
# same thing, but grab the underlying vector directly
function g(v)
    s = zero(eltype(v))
    for (i,xᵢ) in enumerate(v.x) # <--
        s += xᵢ*i
    end
    return s
end

# test performance
v_int   = V(rand(1:10, 100000))

@btime f($v_int) # slow: 59.199 μs
@btime g($v_int) # fast: 30.200 μs

v_float = V(rand(100000))

@btime f($v_float) # 117.999 μs
@btime g($v_float) # 117.999 μs```
Why is the `Int` version getting hit with a performance penalty (and, as puzzling for me, why isn't the `Float64` version)?

I have a function which creates an array of polynomials using `DynamicPolynomials`
`
```function get_H()
    @polyvar h[1:3]
    H = [h[1] h[2]; h[2] h[3]]
    return H
end```
According to `@code_warntype` this is type-unstable
`
```julia> @code_warntype get_H()
Variables
  #self#::Core.Compiler.Const(get_H, false)
  h::Array{PolyVar{true},1}
  b::Array{PolyVar{true},1}
  H::Any

Body::Any
1 ─       ()
│   %2  = (1:3)::Core.Compiler.Const(1:3, false)
│         (h = DynamicPolynomials.polyarrayvar(PolyVar{true}, "h", %2))
│   %4  = (1:2)::Core.Compiler.Const(1:2, false)
│         (b = DynamicPolynomials.polyarrayvar(PolyVar{true}, "b", %4))
│         Core.tuple(h, b)
│   %7  = Core.apply_type(Main.PolyVar, true)::Core.Compiler.Const(PolyVar{true}, false)
│   %8  = Core.tuple(2, 2)::Core.Compiler.Const((2, 2), false)
│   %9  = Base.getindex(h, 1)::PolyVar{true}
│   %10 = Base.getindex(h, 2)::PolyVar{true}
│   %11 = Base.getindex(h, 2)::PolyVar{true}
│   %12 = Base.getindex(h, 3)::PolyVar{true}
│         (H = Base.typed_hvcat(%7, %8, %9, %10, %11, %12))
└──       return H```
should I be worried about this from a performance perspective and how could I fix this? I tried `H=PolyVar{true}[h[1] h[2];h[2] h[3]]` but it seems to be still type unstable

Ptr{Float64} @0x000000011cb68aa0

messages.text:
I am trying to figure out how to improve the run time of the following code. I already tried changing the squares and quartics line to just be s.^2 and s.^4 and it doesn't make a big difference. Any ideas on what I can do to improve the speed here?
```using Statistics, LinearAlgebra, Distributions

function estimator(s, weights)
    squares = mapslices(x -> x .^ 2, s; dims=1)' .* weights
    quartics = mapslices(x -> x .^ 4, s; dims=1)' .* weights
    return mean(quartics; dims=1) ./ mean(squares; dims=1)
end

function simulate(estimator, opt; P, Q, sample_sizes, num_replicates=1000)
    errs = zeros(length(sample_sizes))
    for (i, n) in enumerate(sample_sizes)
        samples = [rand(P, n) for _ in 1:num_replicates]
        err(s) = norm(estimator(s, (exp.(logpdf(Q, s) .- logpdf(P, s)))) - [opt])^2
        IS_errors = err.(samples)
        errs[i] = mean(IS_errors)
    end
    return errs
end

# short hand for profiling.
d = 1
sim(P) = simulate(estimator, 3, P=P,
                  Q=MvNormal(d, 1),
                  sample_sizes=round.(Int64,collect(range(100, stop=10000, length=10))),
                  num_replicates=2000)```

function estimator(s, weights)

    quartics = mapslices(x -> x .^ 4, s; dims=1)' .* weights
    return mean(quartics; dims=1) ./ mean(squares; dims=1)
end

function simulate(estimator, opt; P, Q, sample_sizes, num_replicates=1000)
    errs = zeros(length(sample_sizes))

        samples = [rand(P, n) for _ in 1:num_replicates]
        err(s) = norm(estimator(s, (exp.(logpdf(Q, s) .- logpdf(P, s)))) - [opt])^2

Hey! Running into some issues defining a specific type dependency. I’m looking to do something like this:
```abstract type Abstract{T} end

struct Foo{T} <: Abstract{T}
    x::T
end```
This works fine, I can run `Foo(1.0)` and get a `Foo{Float64}`
However, I also want to create a wrapper-type

```struct Bar{T, C} <: Abstract{T} where {C <: Abstract{T}}
   x::C
end```
Defining the struct above works fine, but errors when I try to construct it
```julia> Bar(Foo(1.0))
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching Bar(::Foo{Float64})```
and if I try to see what constructors where defined for `Bar`, I see that
```julia> methods(Bar)
# 0 methods for generic function "(::Type)":```
